newsitem.title: USA: Nor'Wester stake by India's UB Group cut.
newsitem.headline: Nor'Wester stake by India's UB Group cut.

text.p: Nor'Wester Brewing Co said it amended an agreement with United Breweries of America Inc, an affiliate of the India's UB Group so that United Breweries would invest $5.5 million in Nor'Wester instead of $8.63 million.

Under the original pact, United Breweries was to invest $8.63 million in cash at a price of $2.63 per share in exchange for a 45 percent equity interest in a new entity called United Craft Brewers Inc.
UB Group is one of India's largest beer producers, which produces the Kingfisher brand.

United Craft Brewers would be comprised of the consolidated businesses of Nor'Wester, its affiliate Willamette Valley Inc Microbreweries Across America and Willamette's three units - Aviator Ales Inc of Woodinville, Wash., Bayhawk Ales Inc of Irvine, Calif. and Mile High Brewing Co of Denver, Colo.
Under the amended agreement, United Breweries would invest $5.5 million at a price of $1.75 per share for a 40 percent stake, the company said.
This would reduce the valuation of United Craft Brewers to $14.84 million from $34.23 million, the company said.

"We remain committed to our original strategy of consolidating the businesses of Nor'Wester and its affiliates under the United Craft Brewers followed by our investment in United Craft Brewers," said Vijay Mallya, Chairman of United Breweries of America.

Nor'Wester Brewing reported a first quarter loss of $0.11 per share compared to a profit of $0.02 per share. It attributed the first quarter operating loss mostly to the startup of its brewery in New York.
The company is trying to expand on the east coast of the United States instead of in the Pacific northwest, where brewery competition is intense, it said.
